qas.question: What type of rallies were being held in March of 1991?
There was a nationwide strike being held that was called les envenements and also named what?
After the president declared a state of emergency, what type of curfew was placed on the country?
How many people died over the course of four days?
After all of the governments efforts what types of protests continued?

plausible_answers.text: mass pro-democracy rallies and a nationwide strike

qas.question: What was held in both urban and rural communities throughout the 1990s?
Who opened fire on violent demonstrators?
What was ended by the shootings?
Who stopped coming to Bamako as a result of the 300 lives lost?

context: From 22 March through 26 March 1991, <b5_0>mass <a0_0>pro-democracy<a0_0/> rallies and a nationwide strike<b5_0/> was held in both urban and rural communities, which became known as les evenements ("the events") or the <a1_0>March Revolution<a1_0/>. In Bamako, in response to mass demonstrations organized by university students and later joined by trade unionists and others, <b6_0>soldiers<b6_0/> opened fire indiscriminately on the nonviolent demonstrators. <b7_0>Riots<b7_0/> broke out briefly following the shootings. Barricades as well as roadblocks were erected and Traoré declared a state of emergency and imposed a <a2_0>nightly<a2_0/> curfew. Despite an estimated loss of <a3_0>300 lives<a3_0/> over the course of four days, <a4_0><b8_0>nonviolent<a4_0/> protesters<b8_0/> continued to return to Bamako each day demanding the resignation of the dictatorial president and the implementation of democratic policies.
